title: Part A
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not state that State Bank’s liabilities decrease by $15,000 and/or does not explain that checking accounts are demand deposits, which are liabilities to commercial banks.
The response states that State Bank’s liabilities decrease by $15,000 and explains that checking accounts are demand deposits, which are liabilities to commercial banks.

title: Part B
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

title: Part C
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not state that Jason’s financial asset holdings have stayed the same and/or does not explain that the decrease in Jason’s checking account was offset by the increase in Jason’s bond holdings.
The response states that Jason’s financial asset holdings have stayed the same and explains that the decrease in Jason’s checking account was offset by the increase in Jason’s bond holdings.

title: Part D
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not calculate the maximum amount by which the money supply can decrease throughout the banking system as $300,000 and/or does not show the work.

title: Part E
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not state that unemployment will increase and the price level will decrease and/or does not explain that a decrease in the money supply will result in an increase in nominal interest rates, a decrease in interest-sensitive spending, and a decrease in aggregate demand; therefore, real output will decrease, unemployment will increase, and the price level will decrease.

The response states that unemployment will increase and the price level will decrease and explains that a decrease in the money supply will result in an increase in nominal interest rates, a decrease in interest-sensitive spending, and a decrease in aggregate demand; therefore, real output will decrease, unemployment will increase, and the price level will decrease.
